cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: A soil profile is made of layers called horizons.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Organic litter (leaf litter) at the surface.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Topsoil: dark and humus-rich.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Subsoil: where material can build up (illuviation).

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Parent material: weathered rock.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Two key controls on soil type
cards.back: Climate (temperature + rainfall) and vegetation (leaf litter type/amount).

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Decay into humus: dead plants break down into dark organic matter.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Nutrients released: organic matter becomes available nutrients.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Washing down: dissolved material moves down with water.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Washing out: fine particles and minerals removed from a horizon.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Washing in: materials build up in a lower horizon.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Waterlogging effect: grey/blue colours form due to lack of oxygen.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: A well-mixed, fertile soil in mild climates with deciduous trees.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Temperate mild climate; deciduous woodland/mixed vegetation; good drainage.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back:
1) Leaf litter forms O horizon.
2) Litter decomposes fairly quickly (humification).
3) Organisms mix humus into topsoil (bioturbation).

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back:
4) Nutrients recycled efficiently (mineralisation).
5) Limited leaching (moderate rainfall).
6) Thick brown A horizon; gradual change into B horizon.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Fertile and well structured; thick dark-brown humus-rich topsoil; horizons not sharply separated.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Brown earth: clues in a description
cards.back: Deciduous woodland + mild climate + good drainage; dark well-mixed topsoil; few sharp layers.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Saying strong leaching is the main process (it is limited).

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: An acidic, leached soil under coniferous forest or heath, with clear layers.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Cool and wet climate; coniferous forest/heath (needle litter); heavy rainfall drives water downward; often sandy/acidic parent material.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Strong leaching + eluviation remove minerals/organic compounds from upper horizons; illuviation deposits material in B horizon.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back:
1) Needle litter decomposes slowly → acidic conditions.
2) Acidity limits organisms → weak mixing.
3) Heavy rainfall drives strong leaching.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back:
4) Eluviation removes iron, aluminium and humus from A/E.
5) Pale ash-grey E horizon develops.
6) Illuviation deposits iron/aluminium + humus in B.
7) Thin acidic topsoil → low fertility.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Acidic and low fertility; clear sharply separated horizons; pale leached layer near surface; darker stained B horizon.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Conifers/heath; cool wet/upland; pale grey layer under topsoil, then darker layer below.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Forgetting the pale leached horizon (E horizon).

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: A waterlogged soil where poor drainage causes grey colours.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Very poor drainage; often flat/low-lying or impermeable clay below; water sits in the soil for long periods.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Gleying: waterlogging reduces oxygen, changing iron compounds → grey/blue-grey colours.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back:
1) Water cannot drain away (impermeable layer/flat land/high rainfall).
2) Soil stays waterlogged.
3) Lack of oxygen slows decomposition.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back:
4) Iron is reduced and moved → grey/blue-grey colours.
5) Rust-coloured mottles can appear when iron re-oxidises.
6) Poorly aerated unless drained.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Poor drainage; grey/blue-grey colour often with rusty mottling; lower biological activity; low agricultural potential without drainage.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Gley soil: clues in a description
cards.back: Flat boggy/marshy ground; heavy clay; waterlogging; grey-blue soil with orange/rusty spots.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Describing it as mainly caused by leaching (main cause is waterlogging).

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Quick compare: Brown earth vs Podzol vs Gley
cards.back:
Brown earth: mild + deciduous + good drainage → well mixed, fertile.
Podzol: cool wet + conifer/heath + strong leaching → acidic, clear horizons, pale E horizon.
Gley: poor drainage + waterlogging → grey/blue colours, mottling.
